subjectDescription: Discover a full suite of online business courses that will allow you to make better business decisions and succeed in today's competitive business world. Our courses provide a rich learning experience that will allow you to develop critical business skills in areas such as business... Read more...
title: Advanced Diploma in Production and Operation Management
headline: The free online course on the role of production and operation management in an organization, and program forecasting.
description: This free online production and operations management course will teach you the role of production and operation management in organizations, as well as the phases of product design development. The course will teach you about the requirements for effective inventory management.You will also learn about production planning problems using linear programming, as well as the concept of total quality management, and probabilistic time estimates.
courseDescription:
In this course, you will learn about the role of production and operation management in an organization, as well as the phases of product design development, and time span for forecasting. The use of exponential forecasting models to calculate seasonality, regression analysis, as well as the stock points in a production-distribution system will also be covered in this course. Furthermore, you will learn about the basic inventory model. Then, the course will teach you about the requirements for effective inventory management, as well as material requirements planning (MRP), and the concept of aggregate planning.

Then, this course will also teach you about the techniques for aggregate planning, as well as the mathematical techniques for obtaining optimal solutions. Production planning problems using linear programming, as well as the dimensions of product quality, and the evolution of quality management will also be covered in this course. As a learner, this course will then teach you about the concept of total quality management, the quality tools that aid data collection and interpretation, as well as the implementation of acceptance sampling.

Learners can also gain an understanding of the six sigma components, the various ways for designing product layouts, and the main tools in project management. Lastly, you will learn about performing network analysis using program evaluation and review technique (PERT) as well as the critical path method (CPM) and the use of various probabilistic times estimates. Begin this course now to learn about the maintenance and life cycle of equipment, as well as the future direction of production and operations management.

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital : a downloadable in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • : a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked , posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed : a physical version of your officially branded and security marked in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.

All are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison , please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison , you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our pricing, please visit our Pricing Page

    • Discuss the heritage of operations management.

    • Explain the various classifications of services systems.

  • Lesson Summary
    • Manufacturing is a process of value addition.
    • The following are primary sources of wealth creation: 
      - Agriculture
      - Manufacturing
      - Services
      - Knowledge
    • Value is something which helps in improving customer satisfaction.
    • In the 1990s, China contributed around 3% of global manufacturing output. Presently, China contributes more than a quarter of the global manufacturing output. 
    • In the concept of scientific management, the following are possible:
      - Matching employees to the right jobs
      - Providing the proper training
      - Providing proper work methods and tools
      - Establishing legitimate incentives for work to be accomplished
    • Productivity is simply the ratio of output to input. An operations manager's role is to improve productivity.
    • The following are the productivity variables:
      - Labour
      - Capital
      - Management

  • Lesson Summary
    • The followng are typical phases of product design development: 
      - Concept Development
      - Product Planning
      - Product/Process Engineering
      - Pilot Production/Ramp-Up
    • Concurrent engineering can be defined as the simultaneous development of project design functions with open and interactive communication existing among all team members for purpose of reducing time to market, decreasing cost and improving quality and reliability.
    • There are three types of teams in concurrent engineering, they are: 
      - Program Management Team
      - Technical Team
      - Design-Build Team
    • Tme savings in concurrent engineering programs are created by performing activities in parallel. 
    • The following are basic categories of forecasting: 
      - Extrapolative
      - Causal
      - Qualitative
    • A simple moving average model assume an average is a good estimator of future behaviour.

  • Lesson Summary
    • Forecast Error = Actual Demand for Period, t - Fore for Period, t.
    • When errors that occur in the forecast are normally distributed, Mean Absolute Deviation relates to the Standard deviation as:
      - 1 Standard Deviation = 1.25 MAD
      - I MAD = 0.8 Standard Deviation
    • A tracking signal is a measurement that indicates whether the forecast average is keeping pace with any genuine upward or downward changes in demand.
    • Some examples of causal factors are:
      - Disposable income
      - New marriages
      - Start of housing projects
      - Start of infrastructure projects
      - Cost of living indices
    • The following are type of causal methods:
      - Regression Analysis
      - Econometric Methods
  • Learning Outcomes
  • Having completed this module, you should be able to:
    • Explain stock points in a production-distribution system.
    • Discuss the economic order quantity model.
    • Identify the different variations in the basic EOQ model. 
    • Discuss the concept of production order quantities and production cycling.
    • Explain the ROP for constant demand and lead time.

  • Lesson Summary
    • There are three basic stages in the basic inventory model, these are:
      - Raw Materials
      - Work in Progress
      - Finished Goods
    • Safety stock is an additional inventory that is carried to reduce the risk of running out inventory (a stock-out) during lead time. 
    • There are two conditions for safety stock requirement, these are:
      - Variation in Demand Rate
      - Variable Lead Time
    • The amount of safety stock depends on the following factors: 
      - The average demand rate and average lead time
      - Demand and lead time variability
      - The desired service level
  • Learning Outcomes
  • Having completed this module, you should be able to:
    • Discuss the single-period model or newsboy problem.
    • Explain the concept of discrete and continuous stocking levels. 
    • Identify the requirements for effective inventory management.
    • Discuss the concept of material requirements planning and MRP inputs. 
    • Identify the terms used in MRP processing.

  • Lesson Summary
    • The single-period model (newsboy problem) generally focuses on two costs:
      - Shortage Cost
      - Excess Cost
    • Inventory control is that process through which measures and regulates the inventory.
    • The following are requirements for inventory management:
      - A system to keep track of the inventory on hand and on order
      - A reliable forecast of demand that includes an indication of possible forecast error
      - Knowledge of lead times and lead time variability
      - Reasonable estimates of inventory holding costs, ordering costs, and shortage costs
      - A classification system for inventory items
    • The following is the breakdown of the classes of the ABC analysis:
      - A approximately 10% of items or 6.6% of value
      - B approximately 20% of items or 23.3% of value
      - C approximately 70% of items or 10.1% of value
    • Materialss Requirements Planning (MRP) is a methodology used for planning the production of assembled products.
    • Some items in MRP are produced repetitively while others are produced in batches. 
  • Learning Outcomes
  • Having completed this module, you should be able to:
    • Explain the concept of lot sizing and various models of lot sizing. 
    • Discuss intermediate planning and aggregate planning in perspective.
    • Identify the supply chain and various demand options. 
    • Discuss the basic strategies for meeting uneven demands.

  • Lesson Summary
    • MRP systems have the ability to provide management with a fairly broad range of outputs. 
    • The outputs from MRP systems are classified as:
      - Primary Reports (the main reports)
      - Secondary Reports (the optional outputs)
    • Detemining a lot size to order or to produce is an important issue in inventory management for both independent- and dependent-demand items. 
    • The following are models for lot sizing:
      - Lot-for-Lot Ordering
      - Economic Order Quantity Model
      - Least Total Cost
      - Least Unit Cost
    • An organizations is able to make capacity decisions on three levels, these are: 
      - Long Term
      - Intermediate Term
      - Short Term
    • Aggregate planning strategies can be described under the following strategies:
      - Proactive Strategies
      - Reactive Strategies
      - Mixed Strategies
